In 1973, Matt Glowacki was born without legs, but it wasn’t until a few years ago he realized he was disabled.

Matt never placed limitations on himself, but many others expected less of him and his unconventional lifestyle. Although the Americans with Disabilities act was passed over 25 years ago, eliminating many barriers, the biggest one still remains: the stigma of having a disability. Able Bodied Like Me offers a new way of thinking, opening up the discussion on how disabled people are treated in the United States.

According to the Council For Disability Awareness, just over 1 in 4 of today’s 20-year-olds will become disabled before they reach retirement age. It’s more important than ever to talk about disability and stigma—and learn how to change it, as well as how to interact with people who are disabled in any capacity.

The book is broken into four parts, examining concepts like inclusion, advocacy, and diversity while including timely discussion questions for readers to reflect on throughout the book. The book also identifies and defines Disability Privilege as special benefits people with disabilities receive from able-bodied people simply because of the presence of a disability.
